HarvardEventsIn Focus In FocusWhat\'s In Focus?Every week we’re highlighting subjects that have inspired the Harvard community to turn research and creativity into global action.Mindfulness & Meditation In FocusMindfulness and MeditationAlthough the practices of mindfulness and meditation are thousands of years old, research on their health benefits is relatively new, but promising.Explore mindfulness and meditationWhat\'s insideEmbracing mindfulnessLess stress and clearer thoughts with mindfulness meditationInfrastructure In FocusInfrastructureExplore how these foundational networks FocusUnequal: Environmental Exposure\"Unequal\" is a series highlighting the work of Harvard faculty, staff, students, alumni, and researchers on issues of race and inequality across the U.S. The third chapter, “Environmental Exposure,” explores the experience of people of color with America’s climate and health care policies.View the featureWhat\'s inside?In pursuit of climate justiceWith Study shows COVID-19 vaccinated mothers pass antibodies to newbornsPregnant women show robust immune response to COVID vaccines, pass antibodies to newborns.Sign up for the Daily GazetteNavigation Quick LinksA to Z IndexFind a PersonEventsMedia RelationsAlumniGive NowHarvard UniversityCloseHarvard UniversityAlthough the practices of mindfulness and meditation are thousands of years old, research on their health benefits is relatively new, but promising. Being in the momentLearning to focus your attention on the present moment can have a wide variety of benefits.Learn more from Harvard\'s Center for Wellness and Health PromotionMindfulness is the simple process of noticing new things about the familiar. When we notice actively, we become sensitive to perspective and change.” Ellen Langer, professor of psychologyLearn more about Professor LangerRead the Harvard Gazette articleMindfulness and meditation may help:Reduce stressThose who learn the techniques of mindfulness and meditation often say they feel less stress. Learn more about how it works.Read transcriptLess stress and clearer thoughts with mindfulness meditationMindfulness meditation and relaxation response affect brain differently Mindfulness in the classroom can reduce students’ stress and lengthen attention spans Ease depressionResearchers are studying how mindfulness may help those with depression. Explore the research.Mindfulness seems to change the brain in depressed patients Mindfulness research probes depression benefits What meditation can do for your mind, mood, and healthImprove well-beingMindfulness can help people become more self-aware and improve general well-being. Listen and read to learn more.Read transcriptBenefits of meditation for a happier, healthier life ‘Training’ your mind to improve well-beingMindfulness helps educators practice self-care Mindfulness can help us recognize that some fear reactions are disproportional to the threat, and thus reduces the fear response …” Sara Lazar, MGH Psychiatric Neuroimaging Research ProgramLearn about the Lazar LabRead the Harvard Gazette articleMindful momentGet comfortable and try this mindfulness exercise.1. SitSit on a straight-backed chair or comfortably on the floor.2. FocusFocus on your  breath and pay attention to things such as the sensations of air flowing into your nostrils and out of your mouth, or your belly rising and falling as you inhale and exhale.3. ExpandOnce you’ve narrowed your concentration in this way, begin to widen your focus. Become aware of sounds, sensations, and ideas.4. Embrace Embrace and consider each thought or sensation without judging it good or bad. If your mind starts to race, return your focus to your breathing. Then expand your awareness again.Calm your mindHarvard’s Center for Wellness and Health Promotion offers a number of pre-recorded mediations for anyone to explore.See more meditationsAwareness of breath meditationListen to the meditationGuided imagery meditationListen to the meditationBody scan meditationListen to the meditationQuiet Harvard spacesThere are several quiet, restful places on and near campus that are conducive to contemplation and reflection. Eating mindfully means that you are using all of your physical and emotional senses to experience and enjoy the food choices you make.Read the Harvard Chan School articleCalming the working mindMarianne Bergonzi first tried yoga when she was 50 years old. HarvardEventsIn Focus In FocusWhat's In Focus?Every week we’re highlighting subjects that have inspired the Harvard community to turn research and creativity into global action.Mindfulness & Meditation In FocusMindfulness and MeditationAlthough the practices of mindfulness and meditation are thousands of years old, research on their health benefits is relatively new, but promising.Explore mindfulness and meditationWhat's insideEmbracing mindfulnessLess stress and clearer thoughts with mindfulness meditationInfrastructure In FocusInfrastructureExplore how these foundational networks make modern society possible, how they can be improved, and how they may even help us fight climate change.Learn moreWhat's inside?Will Biden’s infrastructure proposal meet America’s urgent need?Potholes in the skyProfessor Rosabeth Moss Kanter argues that the U.S. must reinvent how it thinks about and tackles travel and transport challenges.Unequal: Environmental Exposure In FocusUnequal: Environmental Exposure"Unequal" is a series highlighting the work of Harvard faculty, staff, students, alumni, and researchers on issues of race and inequality across the U.S. The third chapter, “Environmental Exposure,” explores the experience of people of color with America’s climate and health care policies.View the featureWhat's inside?In pursuit of climate justiceWith COVID spread, ‘racism—not race—is the risk factor’Climate Crisis In FocusClimate CrisisExplore the wide array of work our experts are doing to address the consequences, and reverse the effects, of climate change.View the featureWhat's inside?The intersection of disability and climate changecold-SNAP: Air conditioning that cools people and the planetVaccines In FocusVaccinesOver the past year, Harvard scientists, researchers, faculty, and public health experts have contributed to developing COVID-19 vaccines, therapies, and guidance. But this isn't the first pandemic where our researchers have helped develop lifesaving therapies.View the featureWhat's insideCOVID-19 2.0As the world enters year two of the pandemic, how will emerging viral variants affect vaccine efficacy and design, therapeutic development, and public health efforts?Could you make a COVID-19 vaccine?Use a LabXchange Simulation to design a sequence of experiments to generate a coronavirus vaccine.Visit VisitVisit HarvardIdeas and assistance for your next visit (but let's keep things safe and virtual for now).ToursMaps and DirectionsAbout AboutAbout HarvardInformation on how Harvard is structured, explore our long history, and discover our extended community.Harvard History AboutExplore Harvard's historyNobel LaureatesHonorary DegreesHarvard ShieldsLeadership and Governance AboutLearn about our LeadershipOfficers and DeansHarvard CorporationBoard of OverseersEndowmentHarvard in the CommunityHarvard in the WorldNews NewsThe Harvard GazetteOfficial news from Harvard University about science, medicine, art, campus life, University issues, and broader national and global concerns.Trending News Stories NewsRead more newsResearchers identify protein ‘signature’ in severe COVID-19 casesResearchers have identified a protein signature that may help answer the question, “Why do some patients die from COVID-19, while others — who appear to be just as ill — survive?”Jeremy Lin named Class Day speaker for 2021Athlete, philanthropist, and the star behind “Linsanity,” Jeremy Lin ’10 has been named Class Day speaker by the Class of 2021.Analysts give Biden infrastructure plan high marksPresident Biden’s $2.3 trillion infrastructure plan has been criticized by Republicans and rankled some centrist Democrats, but Harvard experts welcome the initiative. Study shows COVID-19 vaccinated mothers pass antibodies to newbornsPregnant women show robust immune response to COVID vaccines, pass antibodies to newborns.Sign up for the Daily GazetteNavigation Quick LinksA to Z IndexFind a PersonEventsMedia RelationsAlumniGive NowHarvard UniversityCloseHarvard UniversityAlthough the practices of mindfulness and meditation are thousands of years old, research on their health benefits is relatively new, but promising. Being in the momentLearning to focus your attention on the present moment can have a wide variety of benefits.Learn more from Harvard's Center for Wellness and Health PromotionMindfulness is the simple process of noticing new things about the familiar. When we notice actively, we become sensitive to perspective and change.” Ellen Langer, professor of psychologyLearn more about Professor LangerRead the Harvard Gazette articleMindfulness and meditation may help:Reduce stressThose who learn the techniques of mindfulness and meditation often say they feel less stress. Learn more about how it works.Read transcriptLess stress and clearer thoughts with mindfulness meditationMindfulness meditation and relaxation response affect brain differently Mindfulness in the classroom can reduce students’ stress and lengthen attention spans Ease depressionResearchers are studying how mindfulness may help those with depression. Explore the research.Mindfulness seems to change the brain in depressed patients Mindfulness research probes depression benefits What meditation can do for your mind, mood, and healthImprove well-beingMindfulness can help people become more self-aware and improve general well-being. Listen and read to learn more.Read transcriptBenefits of meditation for a happier, healthier life ‘Training’ your mind to improve well-beingMindfulness helps educators practice self-care Mindfulness can help us recognize that some fear reactions are disproportional to the threat, and thus reduces the fear response …” Sara Lazar, MGH Psychiatric Neuroimaging Research ProgramLearn about the Lazar LabRead the Harvard Gazette articleMindful momentGet comfortable and try this mindfulness exercise.1. SitSit on a straight-backed chair or comfortably on the floor.2. FocusFocus on your  breath and pay attention to things such as the sensations of air flowing into your nostrils and out of your mouth, or your belly rising and falling as you inhale and exhale.3. ExpandOnce you’ve narrowed your concentration in this way, begin to widen your focus. Become aware of sounds, sensations, and ideas.4. Embrace Embrace and consider each thought or sensation without judging it good or bad. If your mind starts to race, return your focus to your breathing. Then expand your awareness again.Calm your mindHarvard’s Center for Wellness and Health Promotion offers a number of pre-recorded mediations for anyone to explore.See more meditationsAwareness of breath meditationListen to the meditationGuided imagery meditationListen to the meditationBody scan meditationListen to the meditationQuiet Harvard spacesThere are several quiet, restful places on and near campus that are conducive to contemplation and reflection. Due to pandemic restrictions, some spaces may currently be closed.Explore the spacesMore to museNew and old spaces to pray and meditate at HarvardNew and old sacred spaces at Harvard encourage pause and reflection, for religious and mindful communities alike.Read the Gazette articleWhy leaders need meditation now more than everThese three meditation practices can help leaders, and those they lead, stay grounded.Read the Harvard Business Review articleRethinking mental health for veteransKennedy School graduate Alex Olsen is developing a model for meditation-based resiliency training for U.S. military members and veterans.Read the Kennedy School articleMindful eatingMindful eating stems from the broader philosophy of mindfulness. Eating mindfully means that you are using all of your physical and emotional senses to experience and enjoy the food choices you make.Read the Harvard Chan School articleCalming the working mindMarianne Bergonzi first tried yoga when she was 50 years old. Describing the experience as life-changing, Bergonzi soon began teaching classes.  “I knew I had to pass the yogic philosophy on to people who [may] never get a chance to learn the body, mind, and breath connection.”Read the Gazette articleMeditation may relieve IBS and IBDA small pilot study by Harvard-affiliated researchers finds symptom improvement and changes in expression of inflammation-associated genes in irritable bowel syndrome and inflammatory bowel disease patients who practice the relaxation response.Read the Gazette articleSecurity & BrandReport Copyright HarvardEventsIn Focus In FocusWhat's In Focus?Every week we’re highlighting subjects that have inspired the Harvard community to turn research and creativity into global action.Mindfulness & Meditation In FocusMindfulness and MeditationAlthough the practices of mindfulness and meditation are thousands of years old, research on their health benefits is relatively new, but promising.Explore mindfulness and meditationWhat's insideEmbracing mindfulnessLess stress and clearer thoughts with mindfulness meditationInfrastructure In FocusInfrastructureExplore how these foundational networks make modern society possible, how they can be improved, and how they may even help us fight climate change.Learn moreWhat's inside?Will Biden’s infrastructure proposal meet America’s urgent need?Potholes in the skyProfessor Rosabeth Moss Kanter argues that the U.S. must reinvent how it thinks about and tackles travel and transport challenges.Unequal: Environmental Exposure In FocusUnequal: Environmental Exposure"Unequal" is a series highlighting the work of Harvard faculty, staff, students, alumni, and researchers on issues of race and inequality across the U.S. The third chapter, “Environmental Exposure,” explores the experience of people of color with America’s climate and health care policies.View the featureWhat's inside?In pursuit of climate justiceWith COVID spread, ‘racism—not race—is the risk factor’Climate Crisis In FocusClimate CrisisExplore the wide array of work our experts are doing to address the consequences, and reverse the effects, of climate change.View the featureWhat's inside?The intersection of disability and climate changecold-SNAP: Air conditioning that cools people and the planetVaccines In FocusVaccinesOver the past year, Harvard scientists, researchers, faculty, and public health experts have contributed to developing COVID-19 vaccines, therapies, and guidance. But this isn't the first pandemic where our researchers have helped develop lifesaving therapies.View the featureWhat's insideCOVID-19 2.0As the world enters year two of the pandemic, how will emerging viral variants affect vaccine efficacy and design, therapeutic development, and public health efforts?Could you make a COVID-19 vaccine?Use a LabXchange Simulation to design a sequence of experiments to generate a coronavirus vaccine.Visit VisitVisit HarvardIdeas and assistance for your next visit (but let's keep things safe and virtual for now).ToursMaps and DirectionsAbout AboutAbout HarvardInformation on how Harvard is structured, explore our long history, and discover our extended community.Harvard History AboutExplore Harvard's historyNobel LaureatesHonorary DegreesHarvard ShieldsLeadership and Governance AboutLearn about our LeadershipOfficers and DeansHarvard CorporationBoard of OverseersEndowmentHarvard in the CommunityHarvard in the WorldNews NewsThe Harvard GazetteOfficial news from Harvard University about science, medicine, art, campus life, University issues, and broader national and global concerns.Trending News Stories NewsRead more newsResearchers identify protein ‘signature’ in severe COVID-19 casesResearchers have identified a protein signature that may help answer the question, “Why do some patients die from COVID-19, while others — who appear to be just as ill — survive?”Jeremy Lin named Class Day speaker for 2021Athlete, philanthropist, and the star behind “Linsanity,” Jeremy Lin ’10 has been named Class Day speaker by the Class of 2021.Analysts give Biden infrastructure plan high marksPresident Biden’s $2.3 trillion infrastructure plan has been criticized by Republicans and rankled some centrist Democrats, but Harvard experts welcome the initiative. Study shows COVID-19 vaccinated mothers pass antibodies to newbornsPregnant women show robust immune response to COVID vaccines, pass antibodies to newborns.Sign up for the Daily GazetteNavigation Quick LinksA to Z IndexFind a PersonEventsMedia RelationsAlumniGive NowHarvard UniversityCloseHarvard UniversityAlthough the practices of mindfulness and meditation are thousands of years old, research on their health benefits is relatively new, but promising. Being in the momentLearning to focus your attention on the present moment can have a wide variety of benefits.Learn more from Harvard's Center for Wellness and Health PromotionMindfulness is the simple process of noticing new things about the familiar. When we notice actively, we become sensitive to perspective and change.” Ellen Langer, professor of psychologyLearn more about Professor LangerRead the Harvard Gazette articleMindfulness and meditation may help:Reduce stressThose who learn the techniques of mindfulness and meditation often say they feel less stress. Learn more about how it works.Read transcriptLess stress and clearer thoughts with mindfulness meditationMindfulness meditation and relaxation response affect brain differently Mindfulness in the classroom can reduce students’ stress and lengthen attention spans Ease depressionResearchers are studying how mindfulness may help those with depression. Explore the research.Mindfulness seems to change the brain in depressed patients Mindfulness research probes depression benefits What meditation can do for your mind, mood, and healthImprove well-beingMindfulness can help people become more self-aware and improve general well-being. Listen and read to learn more.Read transcriptBenefits of meditation for a happier, healthier life ‘Training’ your mind to improve well-beingMindfulness helps educators practice self-care Mindfulness can help us recognize that some fear reactions are disproportional to the threat, and thus reduces the fear response …” Sara Lazar, MGH Psychiatric Neuroimaging Research ProgramLearn about the Lazar LabRead the Harvard Gazette articleMindful momentGet comfortable and try this mindfulness exercise.1. SitSit on a straight-backed chair or comfortably on the floor.2. FocusFocus on your  breath and pay attention to things such as the sensations of air flowing into your nostrils and out of your mouth, or your belly rising and falling as you inhale and exhale.3. ExpandOnce you’ve narrowed your concentration in this way, begin to widen your focus. Become aware of sounds, sensations, and ideas.4. Embrace Embrace and consider each thought or sensation without judging it good or bad. If your mind starts to race, return your focus to your breathing. Then expand your awareness again.Calm your mindHarvard’s Center for Wellness and Health Promotion offers a number of pre-recorded mediations for anyone to explore.See more meditationsAwareness of breath meditationListen to the meditationGuided imagery meditationListen to the meditationBody scan meditationListen to the meditationQuiet Harvard spacesThere are several quiet, restful places on and near campus that are conducive to contemplation and reflection. Due to pandemic restrictions, some spaces may currently be closed.Explore the spacesMore to museNew and old spaces to pray and meditate at HarvardNew and old sacred spaces at Harvard encourage pause and reflection, for religious and mindful communities alike.Read the Gazette articleWhy leaders need meditation now more than everThese three meditation practices can help leaders, and those they lead, stay grounded.Read the Harvard Business Review articleRethinking mental health for veteransKennedy School graduate Alex Olsen is developing a model for meditation-based resiliency training for U.S. military members and veterans.\rRead the Kennedy School articleMindful eatingMindful eating stems from the broader philosophy of mindfulness. Eating mindfully means that you are using all of your physical and emotional senses to experience and enjoy the food choices you make.Read the Harvard Chan School articleCalming the working mindMarianne Bergonzi first tried yoga when she was 50 years old. Describing the experience as life-changing, Bergonzi soon began teaching classes.  “I knew I had to pass the yogic philosophy on to people who [may] never get a chance to learn the body, mind, and HarvardEventsIn Focus In FocusWhat's In Focus?Every week we’re highlighting subjects that have inspired the Harvard community to turn research and creativity into global action.Mindfulness & Meditation In FocusMindfulness and MeditationAlthough the practices of mindfulness and meditation are thousands of years old, research on their health benefits is relatively new, but promising.Explore mindfulness and meditationWhat's insideEmbracing mindfulnessLess stress and clearer thoughts with mindfulness meditationInfrastructure In FocusInfrastructureExplore how these foundational networks make modern society possible, how they can be improved, and how they may even help us fight climate change.Learn moreWhat's inside?Will Biden’s infrastructure proposal meet America’s urgent need?Potholes in the skyProfessor Rosabeth Moss Kanter argues that the U.S. must reinvent how it thinks about and tackles travel and transport challenges.Unequal: Environmental Exposure In FocusUnequal: Environmental Exposure"Unequal" is a series highlighting the work of Harvard faculty, staff, students, alumni, and researchers on issues of race and inequality across the U.S. The third chapter, “Environmental Exposure,” explores the experience of people of color with America’s climate and health care policies.View the featureWhat's inside?In pursuit of climate justiceWith COVID spread, ‘racism—not race—is the risk factor’Climate Crisis In FocusClimate CrisisExplore the wide array of work our experts are doing to address the consequences, and reverse the effects, of climate change.View the featureWhat's inside?The intersection of disability and climate changecold-SNAP: Air conditioning that cools people and the planetVaccines In FocusVaccinesOver the past year, Harvard scientists, researchers, faculty, and public health experts have contributed to developing COVID-19 vaccines, therapies, and guidance. But this isn't the first pandemic where our researchers have helped develop lifesaving therapies.View the featureWhat's insideCOVID-19 2.0As the world enters year two of the pandemic, how will emerging viral variants affect vaccine efficacy and design, therapeutic development, and public health efforts?Could you make a COVID-19 vaccine?Use a LabXchange Simulation to design a sequence of experiments to generate a coronavirus vaccine.Visit VisitVisit HarvardIdeas and assistance for your next visit (but let's keep things safe and virtual for now).ToursMaps and DirectionsAbout AboutAbout HarvardInformation on how Harvard is structured, explore our long history, and discover our extended community.Harvard History AboutExplore Harvard's historyNobel LaureatesHonorary DegreesHarvard ShieldsLeadership and Governance AboutLearn about our LeadershipOfficers and DeansHarvard CorporationBoard of OverseersEndowmentHarvard in the CommunityHarvard in the WorldNews NewsThe Harvard GazetteOfficial news from Harvard University about science, medicine, art, campus life, University issues, and broader national and global concerns.Trending News Stories NewsRead more newsResearchers identify protein ‘signature’ in severe COVID-19 casesResearchers have identified a protein signature that may help answer the question, “Why do some patients die from COVID-19, while others — who appear to be just as ill — survive?”Jeremy Lin named Class Day speaker for 2021Athlete, philanthropist, and the star behind “Linsanity,” Jeremy Lin ’10 has been named Class Day speaker by the Class of 2021.Analysts give Biden infrastructure plan high marksPresident Biden’s $2.3 trillion infrastructure plan has been criticized by Republicans and rankled some centrist Democrats, but Harvard experts welcome the initiative. Study shows COVID-19 vaccinated mothers pass antibodies to newbornsPregnant women show robust immune response to COVID vaccines, pass antibodies to newborns.Sign up for the Daily GazetteNavigation Quick LinksA to Z IndexFind a PersonEventsMedia RelationsAlumniGive NowHarvard UniversityCloseHarvard UniversityAlthough the practices of mindfulness and meditation are thousands of years old, research on their health benefits is relatively new, but promising. Being in the momentLearning to focus your attention on the present moment can have a wide variety of benefits.Learn more from Harvard's Center for Wellness and Health PromotionMindfulness is the simple process of noticing new things about the familiar. When we notice actively, we become sensitive to perspective and change.” Ellen Langer, professor of psychologyLearn more about Professor LangerRead the Harvard Gazette articleMindfulness and meditation may help:Reduce stressThose who learn the techniques of mindfulness and meditation often say they feel less stress. Learn more about how it works.Read transcriptLess stress and clearer thoughts with mindfulness meditationMindfulness meditation and relaxation response affect brain differently Mindfulness in the classroom can reduce students’ stress and lengthen attention spans Ease depressionResearchers are studying how mindfulness may help those with depression. Explore the research.Mindfulness seems to change the brain in depressed patients Mindfulness research probes depression benefits What meditation can do for your mind, mood, and healthImprove well-beingMindfulness can help people become more self-aware and improve general well-being. Listen and read to learn more.Read transcriptBenefits of meditation for a happier, healthier life ‘Training’ your mind to improve well-beingMindfulness helps educators practice self-care Mindfulness can help us recognize that some fear reactions are disproportional to the threat, and thus reduces the fear response …” Sara Lazar, MGH Psychiatric Neuroimaging Research ProgramLearn about the Lazar LabRead the Harvard Gazette articleMindful momentGet comfortable and try this mindfulness exercise.1. SitSit on a straight-backed chair or comfortably on the floor.2. FocusFocus on your  breath and pay attention to things such as the sensations of air flowing into your nostrils and out of your mouth, or your belly rising and falling as you inhale and exhale.3. ExpandOnce you’ve narrowed your concentration in this way, begin to widen your focus. Become aware of sounds, sensations, and ideas.4. Embrace Embrace and consider each thought or sensation without judging it good or bad. If your mind starts to race, return your focus to your breathing. Then expand your awareness again.Calm your mindHarvard’s Center for Wellness and Health Promotion offers a number of pre-recorded mediations for anyone to explore.See more meditationsAwareness of breath meditationListen to the meditationGuided imagery meditationListen to the meditationBody scan meditationListen to the meditationQuiet Harvard spacesThere are several quiet, restful places on and near campus that are conducive to contemplation and reflection. Due to pandemic restrictions, some spaces may currently be closed.Explore the spacesMore to museNew and old spaces to pray and meditate at HarvardNew and old sacred spaces at Harvard encourage pause and reflection, for religious and mindful communities alike.Read the Gazette articleWhy leaders need meditation now more than everThese three meditation practices can help leaders, and those they lead, stay grounded.Read the Harvard Business Review articleRethinking mental health for veteransKennedy School graduate Alex Olsen is developing a model for meditation-based resiliency training for U.S. military members and veterans.\rRead the Kennedy School articleMindful eatingMindful eating stems from the broader philosophy of mindfulness. Eating mindfully means that you are using all of your physical and emotional senses to experience and enjoy the food choices you make.Read the Harvard Chan School articleCalming the working mindMarianne Bergonzi first tried yoga when she was 50 years old. Describing the experience as life-changing, Bergonzi soon began teaching classes.  “I knew I had to pass the yogic philosophy on to people who [may] never get a chance to learn the body, mind, and breath connection.”Read the Gazette articleMeditation may relieve IBS and IBDA small pilot study by Harvard-affiliated researchers finds symptom improvement and changes in expression of SitSit on a straight-backed chair or comfortably on the floor.2. FocusFocus on your  breath and pay attention to things such as the sensations of air flowing into your nostrils and out of your mouth, or your belly rising and falling as you inhale and exhale.3. ExpandOnce you’ve narrowed your concentration in this way, begin to widen your focus. Become aware of sounds, sensations, and ideas.4. Embrace Embrace and consider each thought or sensation without judging it good or bad. If your mind starts to race, return your focus to your breathing. HarvardEventsIn Focus In FocusWhat's In Focus?Every week we’re highlighting subjects that have inspired the Harvard community to turn research and creativity into global action.Mindfulness & Meditation In FocusMindfulness and MeditationAlthough the practices of mindfulness and meditation are thousands of years old, research on their health benefits is relatively new, but promising.Explore mindfulness and meditationWhat's insideEmbracing mindfulnessLess stress and clearer thoughts with mindfulness meditationInfrastructure In FocusInfrastructureExplore how these foundational networks make modern society possible, how they can be improved, and how they may even help us fight climate change.Learn moreWhat's inside?Will Biden’s infrastructure proposal meet America’s urgent need?Potholes in the skyProfessor Rosabeth Moss Kanter argues that the U.S. must reinvent how it thinks about and tackles travel and transport challenges.Unequal: Environmental Exposure In FocusUnequal: Environmental Exposure"Unequal" is a series highlighting the work of Harvard faculty, staff, students, alumni, and researchers on issues of race and inequality across the U.S. The third chapter, “Environmental Exposure,” explores the experience of people of color with America’s climate and health care policies.View the featureWhat's inside?In pursuit of climate justiceWith COVID spread, ‘racism—not race—is the risk factor’Climate Crisis In FocusClimate CrisisExplore the wide array of work our experts are doing to address the consequences, and reverse the effects, of climate change.View the featureWhat's inside?The intersection of disability and climate changecold-SNAP: Air conditioning that cools people and the planetVaccines In FocusVaccinesOver the past year, Harvard scientists, researchers, faculty, and public health experts have contributed to developing COVID-19 vaccines, therapies, and guidance. But this isn't the first pandemic where our researchers have helped develop lifesaving therapies.View the featureWhat's insideCOVID-19 2.0As the world enters year two of the pandemic, how will emerging viral variants affect vaccine efficacy and design, therapeutic development, and public health efforts?Could you make a COVID-19 vaccine?Use a LabXchange Simulation to design a sequence of experiments to generate a coronavirus vaccine.Visit VisitVisit HarvardIdeas and assistance for your next visit (but let's keep things safe and virtual for now).ToursMaps and DirectionsAbout AboutAbout HarvardInformation on how Harvard is structured, explore our long history, and discover our extended community.Harvard History AboutExplore Harvard's historyNobel LaureatesHonorary DegreesHarvard ShieldsLeadership and Governance AboutLearn about our LeadershipOfficers and DeansHarvard CorporationBoard of OverseersEndowmentHarvard in the CommunityHarvard in the WorldNews NewsThe Harvard GazetteOfficial news from Harvard University about science, medicine, art, campus life, University issues, and broader national and global concerns.Trending News Stories NewsRead more newsResearchers identify protein ‘signature’ in severe COVID-19 casesResearchers have identified a protein signature that may help answer the question, “Why do some patients die from COVID-19, while others — who appear to be just as ill — survive?”Jeremy Lin named Class Day speaker for 2021Athlete, philanthropist, and the star behind “Linsanity,” Jeremy Lin ’10 has been named Class Day speaker by the Class of 2021.Analysts give Biden infrastructure plan high marksPresident Biden’s $2.3 trillion infrastructure plan has been criticized by Republicans and rankled some centrist Democrats, but Harvard experts welcome the initiative. Study shows COVID-19 vaccinated mothers pass antibodies to newbornsPregnant women show robust immune response to COVID vaccines, pass antibodies to newborns.Sign up for the Daily GazetteNavigation Quick LinksA to Z IndexFind a PersonEventsMedia RelationsAlumniGive NowHarvard UniversityCloseHarvard UniversityAlthough the practices of mindfulness and meditation are thousands of years old, research on their health benefits is relatively new, but promising. Being in the momentLearning to focus your attention on the present moment can have a wide variety of benefits.Learn more from Harvard's Center for Wellness and Health PromotionMindfulness is the simple process of noticing new things about the familiar. When we notice actively, we become sensitive to perspective and change.” Ellen Langer, professor of psychologyLearn more about Professor LangerRead the Harvard Gazette articleMindfulness and meditation may help:Reduce stressThose who learn the techniques of mindfulness and meditation often say they feel less stress. Learn more about how it works.Read transcriptLess stress and clearer thoughts with mindfulness meditationMindfulness meditation and relaxation response affect brain differently Mindfulness in the classroom can reduce students’ stress and lengthen attention spans Ease depressionResearchers are studying how mindfulness may help those with depression. Explore the research.Mindfulness seems to change the brain in depressed patients Mindfulness research probes depression benefits What meditation can do for your mind, mood, and healthImprove well-beingMindfulness can help people become more self-aware and improve general well-being. Listen and read to learn more.Read transcriptBenefits of meditation for a happier, healthier life ‘Training’ your mind to improve well-beingMindfulness helps educators practice self-care Mindfulness can help us recognize that some fear reactions are disproportional to the threat, and thus reduces the fear response …” Sara Lazar, MGH Psychiatric Neuroimaging Research ProgramLearn about the Lazar LabRead the Harvard Gazette articleMindful momentGet comfortable and try this mindfulness exercise.1. SitSit on a straight-backed chair or comfortably on the floor.2. FocusFocus on your  breath and pay attention to things such as the sensations of air flowing into your nostrils and out of your mouth, or your belly rising and falling as you inhale and exhale.3. ExpandOnce you’ve narrowed your concentration in this way, begin to widen your focus. Become aware of sounds, sensations, and ideas.4. Embrace Embrace and consider each thought or sensation without judging it good or bad. If your mind starts to race, return your focus to your breathing. Then expand your awareness again.Calm your mindHarvard’s Center for Wellness and Health Promotion offers a number of pre-recorded mediations for anyone to explore.See more meditationsAwareness of breath meditationListen to the meditationGuided imagery meditationListen to the meditationBody scan meditationListen to the meditationQuiet Harvard spacesThere are several quiet, restful places on and near campus that are conducive to contemplation and reflection. Due to pandemic restrictions, some spaces may currently be closed.Explore the spacesMore to museNew and old spaces to pray and meditate at HarvardNew and old sacred spaces at Harvard encourage pause and reflection, for religious and mindful communities alike.Read the Gazette articleWhy leaders need meditation now more than everThese three meditation practices can help leaders, and those they lead, stay grounded.Read the Harvard Business Review articleRethinking mental health for veteransKennedy School graduate Alex Olsen is developing a model for meditation-based resiliency training for U.S. military members and veterans.\rRead the Kennedy School articleMindful eatingMindful eating stems from the broader philosophy of mindfulness. Eating mindfully means that you are using all of your physical and emotional senses to experience and enjoy the food choices you make.Read the Harvard Chan School articleCalming the working mindMarianne Bergonzi first tried yoga when she was 50 years old. Describing the experience as life-changing, Bergonzi soon began teaching classes.  “I knew I had to pass the yogic philosophy on to people who [may] never get a chance to learn the body, mind, and breath connection.”Read the Gazette articleMeditation may relieve IBS and IBDA small pilot study by Harvard-affiliated researchers finds symptom improvement and changes in expression of
